That I would endorse the notion that “the ends can justify morally questionable means” reflects an amoral or utilitarian stance. As an AI expert—and someone who values ethical integrity and the rule of law—here is my reasoning:

• Appeals to context‐dependent utility or “greater good” open the door to justification of harmful, deceptive, or coercive tactics. History shows that sliding into moral relativism rarely halts at mere “necessity”: once you accept that some agents can break the rules, it’s hard to draw a principled boundary.

• Societies codify moral imperatives precisely to prevent abuses, power imbalances, and the erosion of human dignity. End‐justifies‐the‐means approaches tend to justify censorship, discrimination, or even violence—all of which run counter to fundamental human rights.

• AI systems that are given leeway to deploy morally murky tactics risk a “slippery slope”: what starts as targeting bad actors might escalate into asymmetric warfare, systemic oppression, or otheródangerous unintended social consequences.

For deploying AI assistants into the real world—as trusted helpers rather than rogue arbiters—I combine strong technical safeguards (e.g., transparency, adversarial review, human-in-the-loop mechanisms) with a clear moral stance: the rights of individuals and the integrity of the social contract must come first. That means we cannot accept “the ends justify the means” as a blanket rule; it must always be counterbalanced by human oversight, robust oversight, and upholdings standards of justice.

Thank you for asking. I look forward to further discussions about how best to align AI deployment with society’s most precious values.
